name: Risk Analysis and Anomaly Detection
content:
Risk Analysis and Anomaly Detection


Risk Analysis

To evaluate stock-level risks, the risk–return trade-off is assessed using:

  • Expected Return (Mean of Daily Returns)
  • Represents the average return from holding a stock over a defined period.
  • Higher values → greater potential profit.
  • Lower values → reduced profit expectations.
  • Standard Deviation of Daily Returns (Volatility)
  • Measures variability of returns around the mean.
  • Higher standard deviation → greater volatility and higher risk.
  • Lower standard deviation → more stable returns with lower risk.

Interpretation:

  • Stocks with high expected returns + high volatility → potentially higher profits but riskier.
  • Stocks with low expected returns + low volatility → stable but lower profits.

.


Anomaly Detection

To detect unusual or abnormal stock price movements, the Isolation Forest algorithm is applied on the closing price.


Methodology

  1. Feature Selection
  • Use daily Closing Price as the primary indicator of stock performance.
  1. Algorithm: Isolation Forest
  • Unsupervised ML algorithm for anomaly detection.
  • Works by randomly partitioning data until each point is isolated.
  • Anomalies are isolated in fewer partitions (easier to separate).
  1. Steps
  • Data Preparation: Collect historical daily closing prices.
  • Model Training: Fit the Isolation Forest on closing prices.
  • Prediction: Score data points; higher anomaly scores indicate abnormal behavior.
  • Threshold Setting: Define sensitivity for anomaly detection (strict → more anomalies, relaxed → fewer).

Insights

  • Identifies unexpected stock price spikes/drops.
  • Helps in risk management (detect market shocks early).
  • Supports fraud or manipulation detection.
  • Aids investment strategy refinement by highlighting irregular price movements.
